title: Aussie surgeon says convicted murderer Mark Basa shouldn't be deported back to Papa New Guinea
text:
A man convicted of murdering an airforce cadet should not be deported back to Papua New Guinea, according to a leading surgeon.

Mark Basa was 16-years-old when he was found guilty of Zane McCready's murder in 2006.

The 20-year-old cadet was stomped on, had his throat slashed with a glass bottle and beaten up with a bike chain by a group of 15-football club members in Newcastle, July 6, 2005.

Mark Basa (pictured) was 16-years-old when he was found guilty of Zane McCready's murder in 2006

The 20-year-old cadet (left) was stomped on, had his throat slashed with a glass bottle and beaten up with a bike chain

Basa has been in Sydney's Villawood detention centre since 2018, after spending 12-and-a-half years in jail.

The now 28-year-old has been fighting the Immigration Department's decision not to grant him a visa due to his criminal background and send him back to Papua New Guinea, Nine News reported.

A leading surgeon claims the convicted murderer would suffer starvation within weeks or months if he were to be deported because he had a third of his pancreas removed in 2007.

The surgery came after an accident during a football match with other inmates.

Basa has been fighting the Immigration Department's decision not to grant him a visa due to his criminal background and send him back to Papua New Guinea

Now 28-years-old, Basa has been in Sydney's Villawood detention centre since 2018, after spending 12-and-a-half years' jail (stock)

One of Australia's most experienced pancreatic surgeons Professor Jaswinder Samra, said Basa requires Creon.

Creon is a prescription medicine used to treat people who cannot digest food normally because their pancreas does not make enough enzymes.

The surgeon said Papua New Guinea only held a limited supply of the drug, which costs $100 per 100 tablet bottle, according to the ABC.

Professor Samra also said that Basa needs constant medical attention as well as taking one tablet during each main meal.

'So even if he eats well, he has a healthy diet, he wouldn't be able to absorb food properly and in the long and in the short-run I am concerned that his survival is likely to be shortened,' he told the publication.

'Certainly he would get wasted within a year if he wasn't taking appropriate medications and that would predispose him to a significant risk of infection.'

Professor Samra also said that Basa needs constant medical attention as well as taking one tablet during each main meal (pictured Villawood Detention Centre)

McCready's mother is also fighting for Basa's stay in the country, stating that he did not act alone in the death of her son.

'The attack on my son was obscene but what is even more obscene is that only one person was held responsible and now they are trying to get rid of him,' Ms Lowe told Nine News.

'I never thought it was murder. I argued back then with the prosecution it was a gang attack and that everyone in that gang was equally responsible.'
description: Mark Basa was 16-years-old when he was found guilty of the murder of NSW Airforce cadet Zane McCready, 20, in 2006.
authors: Sahar Mourad For Daily Mail Australia
